reviews.title: Not the best
reviews.text: This market has lots of decent local craft items but the problem is some of the stall holders are so pushy it wears you down, even experienced travellers avoid it

reviews.title: Nothing Special
reviews.text: We went here because we were in the area. Nothing special. Just the usual stuff that is available on every street corner in The Gambia

reviews.title: WELCOME TO THE GAMBIA
reviews.text:
Very interesting to see Arts and crafts batik in senegambia craft market for the Best local Guide to show you around please kindly contact +220 7647423 

Thank you for your kindly attention! 
Welcome to the Gambia smiling coast of West Africa

reviews.title: Average dusty local outdoor market
reviews.text: Typical African market where the same trinkets, crafts, textiles etc are being sold, mostly very dusty. Am the above can easily be found in any same place. Each stall sells everything the same as their neighbors. Even having multiple stalls. I certainly saw, like for like, in Tanzania and Zanzibar. DO not accept the first price. Offer a 1/3 and meet in the middle unless you're very generous and pay their inflated price All good fun and they certainly won't sell at a loss They're great vendors, chatty, friendly and interested in where you're from.

reviews.title: Good souvenirs, many compellingly addressed
reviews.text: A great little market for authentic African souvenirs (bags, keychains, statues, paintings, jewelry). Sellers were incredibly pushy; I couldn't move without being approached forcefully. Tourists were asked to pay double the price, which led to a lot of haggling.

reviews.title: BEAUTIFUL CREATIVITY
reviews.text: After visiting the park, we had the pleasure of strolling through the Senegambia Craft Market, a vibrant and colorful place where local traditions are expressed through a myriad of handcrafted objects. Upon our arrival, we were greeted by a kaleidoscope of colors, with stalls overflowing with carved wooden objects, African ceremonial masks with mysterious patterns, batik fabrics in shimmering hues, traditional clothing, and sparkling jewelry. The welcome from the merchants was warm but urgent, with each of them extolling the beauty and quality of their products. Among the objects on display, we were particularly seduced by the magnificent wooden sculptures, testifying to the talent and know-how of the local artisans. The African ceremonial masks, full of history and symbolism, also captivated our imagination. Batik fabrics, with their intricate patterns and vibrant colors, added a touch of vibrancy to the market, while traditional clothing offered a fascinating glimpse into local culture. The elaborately crafted jewelry, adorned with beads and precious stones, sparkled in the blazing sun. Among the market's treasures, we also discovered magnificent canvas paintings, true works of art that reflect the region's rich culture and artistry. Each painting told a story, capturing the essence and beauty of life in Senegambia. Our visit to the Senegambia Craft Market was an unforgettable experience, immersing us in the heart of local culture and crafts. Between the vibrant colors, beautifully crafted objects, and lively atmosphere of the market, we were transported to a world of beauty and creativity. TRAVELWITHUS.COM FB AND INSTA AROUNDTHEWORLD2023

reviews.title: Hard selling at its worst - avoid this place
reviews.text: I felt pressured into buying items that I did not need from stall holders. It was not a nice experience and it was not what I expected. I would not go there again, the prices are inflated and if you are not a haggler you get ripped off.

reviews.title: Beautyfull stuff (clothes, souveniers)
reviews.text:
There are beautyfull stuff at the market. People are very kind but sometimes its anoying they push you to buy stuff. Let people see for themselves. Pushing to buy is also pushing away. 
Because we left de market and did not buy anything. The 3rth visit i bought Some stuff. 
I bought 6 dresses and 2 Animal Crafts. Very beautyfull.

reviews.title: Not suitable for wheelchair users
reviews.text: One of us is a wheelchair user. The taxi controller knew that and he would also have known that the trip would be disastrous but still he let us go. The road surfaces are so poor that a wheelchair can’t negotiate them. As a result we saw nothing of the market. The taxi driver dropped us outside a shop having parked the taxi 200 yards away. We waited 30 minutes for him to pick us up because of the one way road system and the heavy traffic. Maybe others would enjoy the market but that was our experience.

reviews.title: Craft markets
reviews.text: One of the many craft markets. Small but fine for an hour. However, there's a lot of pushing from the vendors and little acceptance of the word "no."

reviews.title: Not hugely impressed
reviews.text:
Nothing special about this market ,better bargains can be found elsewhere ,
Some of the traders are rude especially the first wood carving stall on the left

reviews.title: Nice market with very nice sellers
reviews.text: The incredibly kind people at the Craft Market often sell the same items for the same price: clothing, wood carvings, bracelets, jewelry, peanuts, and so on. Bargaining is fine, but remember that every Dalasi is incredibly precious to them. These poor, yet incredibly kind people are so grateful for every Dalasi they earn.

reviews.title: Tough Shopping
reviews.text: 99% of the stalls sells the same wares. But if you have the patience to walk around and bear with the 'hassle' of the stall owners calling you....you will find something different...just like we did.

reviews.title: Honeymoon visit
reviews.text: Great little market full of woodworking pieces jewellery and trinkets you will be approached a lot just remember be polite and just say only looking but enjoy the African experience

reviews.title: Be prepared to have a lot of options
reviews.text: It’s beyond impressive that the people of Africa have kept traditional crafting so alive and well. Everything is one of a kind, and so authentic! MOST ITEMS ARE HAND MADE. From paintings, to carvings, to jewelry. You’re sure to fall in love. Also, everything is so well priced. Be sure to enter with some self-control, because it’s easy to want to buy every single thing you see!

reviews.title: Dont Go Alone
reviews.text:
Senegambia market is huge filled with people shoulder to shoulder selling everything from sunglasses to cement and anything inbetween.
The roads are packed with taxis ,stalls it looks totaly unorganised  but i am sure it.
If you get the chance go just to experience Gambian life but do take a guide

reviews.title: Fond memories of Gambia
reviews.text: Badou and Tapha Jewelleries are very friendly men with beautiful, reasonably priced jewelry. They're in the back right corner.

reviews.title: worth seeing
reviews.text: Negotiate all prices, sellers can be quite pushy, pleasantly shady place, conveniently located near various restaurants in the city center

reviews.title: Good market
reviews.text: Much things to look at and much things to but. Remember that you need to discuss the Price and get it down at least 50%

reviews.title: Ferie
reviews.text: Meget spændende,meget anderledes end andre markeder vi har været på, det kan være svært at se ordentligt på noget da alle sælgere er meget anmasende, men samtidig er de også utrolige søde og smilende.

reviews.title: Shopping can be tiring
reviews.text: A small and beautiful market to look around and marvel at, but unfortunately not ideal for browsing and choosing in peace. The vendors are a bit demanding in their sales culture.

reviews.title: Desperate
reviews.text: After visiting Gambia several times I enjoyed talking to the locals in the market and they made me very welcome. Unfortunately this time as no tourists coming in I found it the opposite . I was shouted at by one store owner as i was effecting his business i know thus is a difficult time for gambians but found it very hostile and some if them very angry and aggressive i certainly wont be visiting again

reviews.title: Unsurprising market
reviews.text: Almost everyone sells the same stuff for the same price. And they're appealing. Bargaining is recommended. I did buy a few self-painted tea boxes. Not particularly special, but unique.

reviews.title: hassle !
reviews.text: Such a pity because I wanted to buy several things for the family, but the hassling and pushing by he vendors drove me away very quickly. If they'd just leave people to look, they'd make more sales.

reviews.title: The negotiations remain typically
reviews.text: We've been to this market a few times. It's a fun "kraft" market. Although each stall has a lot of the same items, they make a lot of their own wood carvings. You can also watch the artisans at work. What did take some getting used to was that a deal isn't a deal. If you agree on an amount and they have to give you change, they never do. They go elsewhere for change, come back to say they can't change (and it doesn't matter what amount), and then ask you to buy something else from the stall with the change. We hadn't recognized this bargaining model (it didn't happen on our trips to Southeast Asia). So decide what you want for your change, give it as a tip, or just argue, Dutch style, to get your change. But decide what you want.

reviews.title: Not What it Appears
reviews.text: Some interesting African products but tmany stalls appear to be fronted by an english speaking assistant with the stall owner in the background. Very similar products to many other local markets. Quite surprising that the stallholders were unhappy if you wouldn't enter the stall, but often thanked you for entering even if you didn't make a purchase.

reviews.title: A few tricks
reviews.text:
The trick is when dealing with the stallholders is first of all go and look at what you are wanting to buy get a feeling for the price walk away go and have a drink then take the money out of your purse or pocket and having your hand so that when you go back you tell them that this is all you have money talks louder if they can see it and you will get everything at roughly one third of the price they are wanting

Try it it works

reviews.title: Very nice arts and crafts!
reviews.text:
Very nice arts and crafts! Be adviced, take a good trusty guide for the best prices!
You can find almost everthing nice there. Best wood carvings in town. And after shopping you can drink a beer at ALEX across the street.

reviews.title: run the guantlet
reviews.text: Cheap nic naks in small stalls found at the top end of the strip. Most stalls sell similar products, tie dyes, wood carvings fridge magnets etc. Be prepared to barter and expect to get a bit mithered and hassled as you try to look round. Go early before all the stalls are set up and you will find things much cheaper than inside the hotels themselves.

reviews.title: The place for souvenirs in Kololi
reviews.text: I've been there twice. Once in the late afternoon, when it was very busy, and again early in the morning around 8:30 AM to buy some last-minute souvenirs. That was ideal. Not everything was open yet, but there was plenty of choice, and the vendors hadn't started up yet, so you could browse quietly without being pushed around. There's a wide variety of handmade souvenirs and fabrics. Of course, you do need to bargain hard here.

reviews.title: Supermarket!
reviews.text: A complete chaos, and therefore a lot of fun! You can buy lots of lovely fabrics there to have an African dress made.

reviews.title: Small tourist market
reviews.text: Small market where you can buy mainly wood carvings and other handmade African souvenirs. You'll need to haggle, though, and close a deal for about a third of the asking price.

reviews.title: What an experience
reviews.text: Talk about busy, colourful, sights you wouldn't see in a market in the UK. Our taxi driver had his number plates removed by the police for parking in the wrong area and then had to pay a fine to get them back. Plenty of opportunity for a good haggle and good humored banter. You can buy spices, chickens, fabrics, clothes, belts, shoes, pretty much anything you want.

reviews.title: All the same
reviews.text: At this market you will find the same souvenirs as on Serekunda Market or Brikama.  The only difference is that they are more expensive as this market is for tourists.

reviews.title: Very nice Market
reviews.text: A real nice market with awesome people who all want to sell u something. Best time to go is around the muslim prayer time. You will find what u will looking for here although most vendors sell the same things

reviews.title: VERY NICE CRAFT MARKET
reviews.text: this is well stocked craft market. but if you travel to Baqau. there is a craft market there will be much cheaper plus they sell amazing hand made wood ornaments. senegambia as a whole is just over priced restaurants supermarkets. everything over priced for tourists. I went pharmacy for some ankle sock and creams wanted 1200 dalassi. went to pharmacy in Baqau and kololi and was half price. same restaurants look for local restaurants. there is a kaddy kaddy gambia food gravy round corner. full plate lamb and rice 50 dalassi. it's not glam though. for fruits there is stalls at traffic lights or go serekunda. everything is cheap there. there are wholesale shops for soft drinks and provisions.

reviews.title: Lots of beautiful handmade things.
reviews.text: Here you'll find many things that are cheaper elsewhere. However, this close to the Senegambia Hotel, the asking prices are still a bit higher than, for example, at the market in Serekunda or Brikama. If you really want something, haggling is essential. Start with a quarter of the asking price and don't go up too much.

reviews.title: Craft as Craft can
reviews.text: Very well sorted craft market - mostly statues, woodcarvings, paintings, clothes and even thimbles (I bought 2 for a collector)

reviews.title: Nice to have seen
reviews.text: You really need to be a good judge of your trade to haggle hard. Products are way overpriced. I thought that was a bit of a shame.

reviews.title: Great fun
reviews.text: We had a great couple of hours haggling for a few trinkets to take home to family. I was shown how to play the local game consisting of some beans and a wood carved long dish I think she said it was called Baku Baku. Everyone was very friendly and just wanted you to buy from them, I laughed and explained to one lady I didn't have enough money to spend on every stall, she laughed to so a polite no thank you and I'm all spent up was enough for them to stop, but we never really felt like it was a shark frenzy we thought everyone was very friendly, and would happily go again again for an hour or two.

reviews.title: The same old things
reviews.text:
We had a quick look around the Senegambia craft market which most of the stalls were exactly the same selling wooden carvings which were dusty as been sitting about also bracelets and a few ladies sarongs but nearly all the same items.
Nothing we wanted but they were very good prices for those interested as competitive pricing due to all the stalls having the same things.
It is nice to see all the bright colours and the people were very friendly.

reviews.title: Great for presents
reviews.text:
Nice relaxed market without much hassle. Usual bartering skills required but good fun. Wife bought usual wooden carving and stuff for presents to take home (or tat as I call it)   
Easy to find at crossroads on the strip. 
Pleasant way to spend an hour and support the local trade

reviews.title: Typical African market
reviews.text: I've visited the country several times and usually stay in this area, and I always stop by this market. It's a few stalls selling more or less the same things: figurines, tablecloths, bracelets, dresses... and where you can haggle and make friends with the vendors. It's worth a visit.

reviews.title: Nice little market
reviews.text: Nice little market, no huge hassle, but they do try their best to sell you something with a good story. Lots of the same.

reviews.title: nice to walk around
reviews.text: You're accosted from all sides, but it doesn't get nerve-wracking. These people have to make a living from what they sell, and they usually offer the same thing. We did buy some wood carvings (keychains, bottle openers, board games, etc.) and a few batik cloths. Don't forget to haggle over the price: it's part of the job.

reviews.title: Lots of junk
reviews.text: This craft market isn't particularly special. It mainly sells junk. The vendors are pushy.

reviews.title: Bra lokal marknad
reviews.text:
Stor och bra marknad för lokalbefolkningen, trånga gränder och mycket att se.
Kryddor, kläder, husgeråd, färsk fisk och levande djur. 
Gå dit på förmiddagen, då det är svalare.

reviews.title: Large and colourful, very busy
reviews.text: Lots to see, probably not much you would want to buy, great to experience local life and ways and flies!

reviews.title: Quaint
reviews.text:
Lots of little stalls selling carvings etc 
Like everywhere in The Gambia the try to get your business but just say no thank you

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: Took a walk around this market, met some great people, my wife had her hair platted with extensions by Ramada and her daughter (stall no. 48) and it looks fantastic, whilst I waited I ended up playing a game of Wawaw and drinking green tea with one of the stall holders.  I and see Jimmy (stall 55) great guy to barter with.  Will visit again.

reviews.title: Small and quaint
reviews.text: This was a lovely little market designed to sell to tourists. Slightly more expensive than going to the city market, but we enjoyed the banter.

reviews.title: Nice relaxed market for clothes and bracelets
reviews.text: Lots of the same stuff, but nice to walk around during day time, than you see the best. Of course everybody wants you to enter their shops...

reviews.title: Craftmarkets
reviews.text:
It is a craftmarket like there are a lot in the Gambia. It is just nice but small.
So just pass it by and if not; you not miss a thing

reviews.title: An experience
reviews.text:
If you can handle high pressure selling and sob stories go for it. Not much to see as all stalls very much the same. Great if you want wooden crafts, jewellery or clothing but not much else.
Worth a visit as it’s true Gambia but it’s hard work they all want your time and your money

reviews.title: market visit
reviews.text: It's a huge market. Everything is very low, so my 6'2" husband had to constantly bend over. It was really interesting to see.

reviews.title: Great stuff to buy
reviews.text: One stop shopping for your crafts and what not. Great varieties from local jewelries, masks, painting and so on.

reviews.title: Haggling is mandatory
reviews.text: A small craft market with a variety of souvenirs. Be sure to haggle to get a good price. Calm and assertive is the best way to go.

reviews.title: Difficult to say no
reviews.text: We found, of all places we visited in The Gambia, the salesmen and women at this market were the most 'aggressive'. There are some nice crafts on sale but every single person literally drags you into their shop. They put stuff in the hands of our todler to make us feel obligated to buy. Of course they want to make money, but this was too much for our taste.

reviews.title: Handy little craft market for Senegamia area browsers,,.
reviews.text: Situated at the top of The Strip service road next to Sara and opposite Alex. Africa brik-a brak  that you can barging for, some import not local at all. Useful that you can get some repairs done and if you know what you want some things made.  I found a contact at Alex bar that got be a good pair of sandles hand resoled and sown D250, throw away case in UK.  And a piece of silver work made up from a photo. Again reasonable but made off site from market so took a few days.

reviews.title: Shopping
reviews.text: We met a guy in a bar one night who said he could make carvings of our pets, so I asked if I could see his work and it was spot on, we agreed a price I messaged a photos of the dogs and paid a deposit, he issued a receipt with phone number and all info, if you want anything like this go to unit 12, you will not be disappointed. Also the lady in 13 is quite aggressive and very pushy so I bought a Gambian shirt of a polite lady in 14 hassle free

reviews.title: Not a quiet visit
reviews.text: Unfortunately, they don't learn how to stop; they pull you in almost everywhere. It's impossible to look around in peace here, such a shame. So, off to Serunda Market instead.

reviews.title: Do all your Gambian gift shopping in one place!
reviews.text: Senagambia Craft Market is many things: busy, fascinating, unchanging and exciting. I first visited in the late 90s and I'm almost convinced the same stuff was still on sale. The traders are still extremely polite but can be very pushy and the craftspeople who work in the market are still making wonderful stuff at a price that is unbeatable - but you do need to haggle. The woodcarvers near the entrance are a lovely bunch of lads. They work so hard to produce really well made items. I commissioned a carved elephant and collected it the very next day. It might be as well to remember that there is a weight limit on planes as that almost turned into a very expensive elephant indeed. Fortunately I got away with it... Don't be afraid to haggle and remember that the price given for the goods on sale can be reduced if you push - just, not too much eh? Its better when both parties get a good deal. Enjoy the market and make sure you go right to the very end where there is a stall that promises no hassle. Just don't believe a word of it! lol. The market takes about an hour or two to look around properly. I returned several times and found something new to look at on each occasion.

reviews.title: Peter crowe
reviews.text: The craft market situated at the entrance to the strip is a must place to visit  for gifts or just to look around plenty of hand made items for sale with no set prices  "haggle away  great fun

reviews.title: Holiday
reviews.text: Love visiting any market in the world. This market has many stalls lots of banter, Lots of bracelets for sale, everyone wants you the look in their shops on their stalls. Love chatting with the locals here people are so friendly and poilet. Go and take in some culture.

reviews.title: Hot and traditional craft market
reviews.text: Worth a visit, but be prepared to haggle and resist the pleas to by something/ anything from every stall!

reviews.title: Too much hassling
reviews.text: Here are so many stalls selling the same thing & nearly all stall holders are part of a “ cartel”. Beware being dragged inside to negotiate a price which is always, at least double if not more the correct price. Much of the goods are substandard. Many of the carvings are of a poor quality and they are liable to split when brought home.

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: There are quite a few stalls which are packed in to a relatively small space. As always the Gambian people were very friendly and it was fun bartering with the stall holders.

reviews.title: Some memories
reviews.text: Place to find souvenirs. People are not easy to bargain with. Better to go to brikama, similar but actually people from kololi buy at brikama. But it's still a nice place to walk around. Free entry. Open from 9am to 6pm.

reviews.title: Worth a nose
reviews.text: Strolled in as it was very near to our hotel, all the traders were very quick to want to pounce, this was probably as the season has just started but they were all friendly enough

reviews.title: nice little market
reviews.text: Nice little market. Well worth a visit and dont forget to barter when you get there. It is also right on the beach and next to Dominos bar

reviews.title: An experience not to be missed
reviews.text: If you like to haggle go here, there is lots of choice and you can certainly pick up an African object which has been locally made by hand

reviews.title: Not a bad option if you are not venturing.....
reviews.text: It's a good option if you are not venturing very far, don't have much time and want to get a feel of purchasing items if you are staying in that location. Bartering is the key to most transactions in Gambia.

reviews.title: Nice visit
reviews.text: Nice stuff, but very geared towards tourism. Few locals and tourist prices. Still worth a visit.

reviews.title: Delicious curry
reviews.text: We had a fantastic curry! It's a bit pricier than average, but it's worth it! You get a basket of bread as a starter. The atmosphere inside is a bit less cozy, but the food was delicious. Later, a South African band performed here. Highly recommended if you love curry!

reviews.title: Level but
reviews.text: This craft market is located at the end of the strip on the right side near the crossing. yes, it is a tourist trap but on the other hand you get the opportunity to learn the game of buying souvenirs in a small market. in a bigger market like the one in banjul - albert market - is the same game only 10 times bigger . You find literally everything there, even several times. So the best thing is to go around and see what is available where. Your second round you can decide what you buy where. If you want to walk around at your pace, just tell them that you are looking around . when you want to buy make sure to cut the price. if it is too low, they will not sell, don't worry.

reviews.title: Hectic crowd of sellers
reviews.text: Since there are only shops selling woodcarvings, textiles, souvenirs, and silver, the selection is very limited. This means that once you've visited this craft market, you won't return. The selection is very limited; they should sell some new and different items.

reviews.title: Just do it
reviews.text: A well-organized market with nice items. It works the same here as everywhere else, of course, but you might still be able to snag a bargain.

reviews.title: full
reviews.text: The market is packed with stalls and booths. Everyone is asking to take a look. Beautiful items, but also a lot of the same stuff.

reviews.title: wood carving in abundance
reviews.text: nice wood carving market where you can buy all sorts of things, also various clothes at good prices, easy to find at the beginning of the strip

reviews.title: tourist attraction.
reviews.text: Whilst i was living there this market was where i had dresses made,  sandals etc. Good place to buy your presents for home. Lovely friendly people, but shop around as prices differ!

reviews.title: Many providers, few tourists
reviews.text: Lots of standard offerings, but they also have men who sometimes create beautiful products. I've had a beautiful walking stick made there twice now. Prices are higher than in Serrekunda or Banjul, but of course, negotiable.

reviews.title: Very average
reviews.text: A secluded market with so-called African crafts, but everything you see there is everywhere. Average wooden statues, average beads, average sandals—in short, everything average. Fortunately, it's free to enter.

reviews.title: Tourist junk
reviews.text: Just the usual tourist junk in a very depressing setting. Not much pressure from the traders, but we were there in the run-up to the state of emergency, so think most traders more concerned about the future. Hope all goes well for them.

reviews.title: Good selection items, lots of haggling
reviews.text: Visited twice, 1st time didnt make it past 1 stall before we spent up. 2nd time made past 2 or 3 then we'd bought what we went for. Lots of haggling to be done.

reviews.title: Eeg nice market
reviews.text: Touristy market, but very pleasant and cozy. The vendors are incredibly friendly, even if you're just asking for something or just browsing. Of course, they're all eager to sell something, but they're all friendly.

reviews.title: Far to intence
reviews.text: I don't know if it is that im a swede but i feelt very uncomfortable at this market. We took two steps in and instantly about 10 people started to grab us och talk and pull just to look at their shop, and I totally understand that.  Still it feels far to tourist like. Everyone sells the same things, wooden statues and batik fabriks and sure they are beautiful, but they was manufactured. So, nothing special but if your looking for souvenires, this is the place.

reviews.title: Cozy market
reviews.text: Fun souvenirs at this woodcarving market. People are a bit pushy, but friendly and welcoming. And they can make whatever you want if you have a sample.

reviews.title: Looking for African keepsakes
reviews.text:
Visited 2 days ago
As is usual no price tags pure barter system, felt slightly pressurised to buy things we were not interested in buying. Purchased lovely peanut cookies and oranges and bananas from lady I. The photo. I am going to call her big mama but I am sure she has another name.

reviews.title: So many stalls
reviews.text:
Objectively the vast majority of the stalls had all the same stuff, but that's not a problem. Don't try to go in all the stalls! Do go with the flow and let yourself be invited in to see the wares, the stall holders try very hard. Do play a game of Gambian mankala, you do have the time, and relax about it.
Do bargain well but politely, you will get a fair price.

reviews.title: outside you can't see how nice it is inside
reviews.text: It's definitely for tourists, but there are some really nice entrepreneurs inside, like the tailor who sits behind the sewing machine in his small shop. And all the way at the back, at number 46, is Bubba, a very friendly guy who's not pushy and can show you how everything is made. You have to go behind the building with him, but there you can watch his woodcarver create the figures on the spot.

reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.text: Lots of wood hand crafted items, nice souvenirs, but you need to negotiate for a reasonable price. The vendors will ask sometime ridiculous prices but if you stay strong you can get a good bargain.

reviews.title: Overwhelming at first
reviews.text:
There are some beautiful items available in this market but the constant hassle from the stallholders can make it difficult to focus on what is available.  I found it very overwhelming at first but grew to love it. Once you realise that they are genuinely just trying to make money to feed their families it becomes more understandable.

Some of the wood carvings are works of art. Clothes are a bit hit and miss but perfect for holidays. Great for little gifts. Prices are higher than other Gambian markets as it is a tourist area. Be prepared to haggle, it is half of the fun. Keep your money close to you and enjoy the atmosphere. I've had great fun with some of the stallholders while waiting for things to be made for me.

reviews.title: Wander after lunch
reviews.text:
Had a wander after lunch. 
You can have a great time and fun with the sellers but you need two things.

Be able to drive a hard bargain.

Have good communication skills and they are good sellers but also lovely.
Enjoy

reviews.title: Interesting but not best value
reviews.text:
The Positives:
Interesting area to browse and close to all the main Kololi hotels. Good range of crafts that make good tourist souvenirs. Interesting beak from hotel/pool/beach. 

The Negatives:
The merchandise is very tourist oriented and the best prices you can get here are much higher than you can get elsewhere. Some stall holders are too pushy - once you show even the slightest interest it is hard to get away without buying something. 

Overall, it is an interesting place to visit, but if you have the time, it is much better to visit Banjul market where you will find a much wider authentic range and get lower prices.

reviews.title: Nice things, but so much hassling
reviews.text: We didn't make it past the third stall - the sellers go hard here trying to sell all of their things. However, they did have some very nice things here. Be aware that you can easily buy everything for a third of the price that they're asking if you negotiate for a bit.

reviews.title: Very quiet
reviews.text: We were there around 10 a.m. and there were only eight tourists in total. It was mostly the same, which wasn't surprising.

reviews.title: High pressure doesn't begin to describe it
reviews.text: We stopped in the evening to view the wares and were literally dragged into some stalls. We felt like we had fallen into a shark tank during a feeding frenzy.

reviews.title: Nice market
reviews.text: Take your time to visit this market. Talk to the sellers and be fair and they will be fair too. Haggle and you will arrive at a price that is acceptable to both parties.

reviews.title: Good selection of crafts
reviews.text: The craft market is convenient if you are staying in the Senegambia/Kololi area.  The selection is good and the vendors willing to negotiate.  They can be aggressive, but not as pressing as other places in Gambia.

reviews.title: Nice outing
reviews.text: A nice tourist spot to buy souvenirs! It's great to see local artists at work carving wood.

reviews.title: Nice local market
reviews.text: It's truly African; they try to sell you everything. Just be clear and don't promise anything. That way, it stays fun.

reviews.title: Shopping for souvenirs
reviews.text: If you can ignore the hassle this is a lovely place to shop. Much less hassle than at other craft markets. Most stalls will find you whatever you want if you can't see it.

reviews.title: Nice market for souvenirs
reviews.text: Nice, small market. Friendly people with whom I had a lot of fun. I bought a lot of wood carvings there and always received my change politely. If you're in Gambia and want to find some nice souvenirs, I recommend visiting this market. Don't forget to haggle. They enjoy it.

reviews.title: Our first experience
reviews.text: Be wary here; you're always the first customer, and there's no change. Instead, you can choose something else and pay extra if necessary. Not a good first introduction to Gambia.

reviews.title: A regular local market is cheaper and more varied
reviews.text: Last year I bought a pair of long pants there, which I wore for 10 minutes, but then they ripped. I had the tear repaired, but the pants were rotten. After falling apart three times, we gave up. This year I bought one blouse there for 700 Dalassies. We bought two pairs at the regular market for 500.

reviews.title: Craft market
reviews.text: I enjoyed the hustle bustle of the market. I saw and bought many different crafts as well as getting my hair braided. The only downside is the relentless badgering of the vendors to get you to buy their wares........which is understandable but became tiresome.

reviews.title: Easy to get to but a bit over-rated...
reviews.text: Don't really buy tourist bling and do consider a lot this is actually mass produced somewhere else. Colourful and worth a few selfie photos.  A taxi ride into Serekunda will get you to a genuine Gambian trading market, realistic prices, be prepared to haggle and ask the ladies before you take photo.

reviews.title: Great for first-time visitors to Africa
reviews.text: A market brimming with African clothing and handicrafts. Great for anyone looking to buy a trinket. Unfortunately, you quickly get fed up with it, unable to move another step until someone jumps on your neck to buy something and keeps harping on about it. I found that quite annoying. You also need to be able to handle the "haggling culture." This game of overcharging and bargaining has to be something you really enjoy. I wasn't particularly bothered by it. My wife loved it. So, it's a personal matter. In any case, be careful not to buy anything too big or too heavy, like wood carvings, because you'll be stuck with your baggage allowance at the airport. There's also a big difference in quality in batik clothing, as we discovered after hand-washing it in our hotel room. But unfortunately, I can't advise on what's good and what's not.

reviews.title: Better elsewhere in Gambia
reviews.text:
The Senegambia craft market is at the left when entering the Senegambia strip, the sellers were rather pushy during this low season.
Lots of things to buy, ideal for those who don't like to leave the strip.
Prices are higher than at other places. Dark during evenings.
Try the Brikama craft market, and you will be impressed

reviews.title: Market visit.
reviews.text: Nice market with a lot of shops. They all have there own handcrafted materials. You can see nice woodwork, cloth and other things. Try the  juices at the main gate.

reviews.title: If you need anything before going back, you find it here
reviews.text: If you need anuthing to buy before going home, go there. Everything is hathered under the same roof. Remember dealing! Not the price they give to you, it's like auction

reviews.title: Don't let yourself be forced but enjoy the African Way of shopping.
reviews.text: A super fun market with hundreds of stalls, all eager to sell you something. Stay polite and do your own thing in this bargain paradise.

reviews.title: Maze
reviews.text: It's huge, and you could easily get lost. Everything is for sale. Highly recommended if you want to see how locals shop.

reviews.title: Lots of little things to buy for familly and friends
reviews.text: Nice little market with jewary bags that kind of stuff just off the strip very busy so keep an eye on you bags nice people.

reviews.title: a real tourist trap
reviews.text: Prices are much higher than at the market in Serrekunda. The vendors are VERY pushy. Not really worth a visit.

reviews.title: interesting caft market, nice place to visit
reviews.text: like all other gambian craft markets we can find a bit of all hand made jewellery, bags and colourfull clothes, people are very friendly and its well located at the center of Senegâmbia.

reviews.title: Very Interesting Market for Loacl Handicraft.
reviews.text:
There are many small stalls displaying hand crafted goods. Some of the carving is superb and very cheap considering the work that has gone into it.
There are of course many trinkets, drums, local clothes, carvings etc.
The people there are extremely friendly and desperate for you to buy from them, without being pushy.
A very interesting place to vist.

reviews.title: Lively market
reviews.text: Good busy and buzzy market. Very enthusiastic stall owners willing to do a deal ! Rather large too. Loads of different stalls and lovely colours abound. See the fish etc etc.

reviews.title: Nie bardzo duży market w centrum
reviews.text: Market, który da się w miare szybko przejsc i sie nie zgubić. Ludzie nagabują ale tak jest wszędzie. Pamiątki głównie materiały, koszulki, spodnie, parea, biżuteria (rózne bransoleteczki naszyjniki) i maski na ścianę. Produktów spozywczych regionalnych nie ma.

reviews.title: Matkamuistojen shoppailuun, mutta myyjät ovat hieman päällekäyviä
reviews.text:
Tämä on hyvä paikka käydä hakemassa matkamuistoja kotiin, sillä sieltä löytää niin koruja, käsintehtyjä puutuotteita kuin vaikkapa rumpuja. Muista tingata hyvin!

Myyjät ovat hieman liian innokkaita myymään ja tällaiselle suomalaiselle se tuntuu aika oudolta...

reviews.title: Manic, colourful and fun.
reviews.text: Exactly what you would expect from a West African market, busy, colourful, noisy.  Sadly couldn't find the shirt I wanted, but didn't have much time to explore.

reviews.title: high-quality craftsmanship
reviews.text: It's great to see the locals at work. It's annoying, though, that they can be so whiny for attention. "You are my best friend, I'll give you the best price" is the most common phrase heard at the market.

reviews.title: More of the same
reviews.text: More of the same. The same wooden statues, necklaces, etc. Very busy vendors, and ultimately not worth a visit. The items are simply too expensive.

reviews.title: Najlepsze miejsce z pamiątkami
reviews.text: Wszystkie możliwe pamiątki kupicie właśnie tam. Szeroki wybór dzianin, wyrobów z drewna oraz magnesów na lodówkę. Te ostatnie są dość drogie w porównaniu z Europą - od 100 do 150 dalasi.

reviews.title: Drogo - w sklepach hotelowych wywoławczo połowę taniej...
reviews.text:
Ogólnie ciekawe miejsce, na którym jest mnóstwo rękodzieła oraz miejscowych ubrań - znajdziemy tam różnego rodzaju koraliki, czapki, drewniane maski i wiele wiele innych drobiazgów. Wadą miejsca jest bardzo duża "upierdliwość" sprzedających i bardzo wysokie na dzień dobry ceny... np. w sklepie hotelowym było około połowę taniej na start...
najlepszym sposobem na spokojne pooglądanie targowiska - było mówienie, iż nie zna się angielskiego...
Miejsce jest atrakcyjne dla osób chcących zobaczyć miejscowe rekodzieło.

reviews.title: Kameralnie :-)
reviews.text:
Polecam na zakup drobnych upominków .
Tylko pamiętaj o zasadzie targuj ile się da z uśmiechem na twarzy ;)

reviews.title: Craft market
reviews.text: They have a lot but they became hostile when we did not buy at there shop. It is not as nice as it use to be. Maybe better when you shop with a husband with you instead of just two women...

reviews.title: Good for gifts
reviews.text: Good for gifts, but don't buy straight away , tell them what you want to pay, walk off and they will come after you.

reviews.title: Very aggressive seller
reviews.text: Small market with lots of salesmen hunting  for the tourists. You can find the standard range of useless nick nacks. Prices are very high. The fruit seller women at the entrance are much more authentic Gambian and certainly worth a chat and spending a few dalasi for a banana or so.
My only advice is remember to haggle and don't buy first time as there are similar or same item at each stall x

reviews.title: ok for the new visitor
reviews.text: get all Gambian trinkets and stuff for presents but do haggle its a must but don't be pushed into buying what you don't want

reviews.title: leuke markt
reviews.text: aardig marktje, veelal dezelfde spullen, je kunt kleding op maat laten maken, besef dat ze teveel vragen en je moet onderhandelen

reviews.title: Better markets close by
reviews.text: I pass through this market often.  I find the people can be a bit aggressive on some visits.  I find the prices a bit higher than if I travel a bit farther to the Baku Market where I find I am not hassled as much with a larger selection of items.

reviews.title: An experience !!
reviews.text: This market was manic amazing dirty unbelievable place they were selling chickens fruit Shea butter handbags clothes food aluminum cooking pots and everything else you could think of ! People were pushing wheelbarrows full of stock in narrow walkways full of people ! The noise was incredible but all the people were smiling! Women had babies on their backs or breastfeeding whilst selling the goods ! There were hundreds of stalls all the same I cannot believe they ever sold it all if anything! But you have to go to believe it

reviews.title: Much of the same
reviews.text: As at so many craft markets in Gambia, you see a lot of the same things here. Bracelets, wood carvings of varying qualities, fabrics, and dresses. It doesn't really impress.

reviews.title: Waste of time
reviews.text:
Can't really agree with the positive past reviews of this small overly priced market. 

Every vendor uses the same selling phrase...
"As I'm their first customer...I'll get a special price "!!!

The inflated prices are higher than hotel and other markets. 

Of course I bartered but the price still ended up higher than other places. And no...I am very good at this. I'm world travelled and yet their prices are not really negotiatable. 

Have a quick mooch but don't go past 1800. It shuts which is a shame as during the day there's no atmosphere. 

Would I go again.....?  No

Go to Serrekunda Market instead.

reviews.title: What hospitality
reviews.text: Lovely market with very friendly people. Lots of handicrafts. They're obviously eager to sell. Who wouldn't be in Gambia? Jaw the Musickman makes beautiful things. It's a great place to sit down and chat. Absolutely fantastic.

reviews.title: Good experience but lots of hassel
reviews.text:
Enjoyed looking round, we did get hassled to buy everything though.  We did buy some drums which were excellent.

A nice experience just stay strong you can say no!

reviews.title: It is what it is .
reviews.text: As per tittle it is what it is ,, worth a look , you will be hassled but you will be anywhere like this in TG ,, but most of the stalls sell the same thing ,,but hey you are in Africa .

reviews.title: would sell more with less hassle
reviews.text:
love having a look around the market but tends to be a rush as you do get a lot of hassle to buy 
if store holders gave you time to look at your own pace they would sell a lot more

reviews.title: Worth a short visit
reviews.text: Nice, but nothing special. You have to know Gambia a little to know how to interact with the people.

reviews.title: Cultural experience!
reviews.text: Nice little market for proper Gambian souvenirs.  All the stalls are mainly the same and sell the same things, carvings, jewellery, fabrics and bags.  The sellers will try and get you into their shop and force you to buy their goods.  If you don't want it, just a polite 'no thank you' and move on.  There is no fixed price on anything so they will ask you for your best price.  If you ask them to give you a price, barter down until you are satisfied.  I bought a nice wooden carving there where the guy told me 850 dalasis.  I ended up paying 300!

reviews.title: Good to have look at least two or three times.
reviews.text: You may find there a lot of wooden hand made masterpieces. If you like some thing but you are still not fully convinces you may ask to refresh colours before buying. The wooden masterpieces are really good but sometimes they lack of colours. Sandpaper or paint to wood would be of great use as a present. I bought on stall 77 from charming and very gifted guy huge chess (50 x 50 cm) with terrific big figures (11-17 cm).

reviews.title: More Relaxed than Serekunda
reviews.text: A good collection of stalls selling jewellery, wood carvings, batik, accessories etc. Most of the stalls sell similar things to each other but lovely items nevertheless. The locals will hustle for business but in a milder manner than the stalls in Serekunda. It is not so hectic so you have more time to browse and consider. I wish more tourists visited the market as the locals there really need your business - many of them perhaps only selling one item a day, My favorite stall was Roy's which is located towards the back (so make sure you don't leave him out or spend all your money too early!) He had a wonderfully carved giant crocodile that had taken him over 2 months to make. I would have loved to have purchased it but my budget would not have given him the fair price he deserved. He was also a very lovely man and advertises his stall as being 'hassle free' and that's exactly what it was.

reviews.title: A walk through the life of a Gambian Craftsman
reviews.text: I wouldn't necessarily say that this market is any cheaper than anywhere else ,nor would I recommend it for those of you who don't like a 'hand's on approach' to business... But if you are curious, I urge you to speak to some of these traders to find out the story behind it all. For example, one individual, real name yusupha who calls his stall at the very back of the market 'Roye's' had carved a lifesize crocodile out of wood, it had taken him 3 months to intricately carve all the amazing detail and yet was prepared to start bartering at the equivalent of £25 for it (picture attached) Some reviews call some of these people's products tat or knock offs from serrekunda market. Please reflect on your ignorance for one moment. A lot of these people know anything else than the artistry of these crafts, they may be illiterate in some cases but can create amazing things. So spending an hour or so down this fascinating part of the otherwise westernized Senegambia strip will truly open your eyes. There are some brilliant unique items to buy, which unlike the shops on the strip, go directly to the traders, who deserve it for their tireless effort. They will be inconsistent, they will beg you to buy, but they appreciate your interest in their artisan trade equally. I do warn you though, that you probably won't leave empty handed, but for a fair price for everyone.

reviews.title: looking for an experience
reviews.text: Take a leisurely walk around the craft market which has fantastic local carvings & jewellry. You can have fun haggling with the locals.Try the local street food

reviews.title: Craft market on the left of the strip
reviews.text: Very colorful market, lots of handicrafts are made here. People are a bit pushy, they like to sell you something, so haggle.

reviews.title: It's going well
reviews.text: Lots of touristy stuff, it's more fun to browse at Serekunda market. It's fun to see and great for bargaining.

reviews.title: Lots to see
reviews.text: Lots of interesting little bits to buy, you have to barter very hard and can be a little intimidating if you don't be firm. The products are usually good with lots of carvings, art and local jewellery etc, also good for little shoe repairs if needed.

reviews.title: Mostly for tourists
reviews.text: Good assortment of tourist souvenirs.Clean, close to restaurants and charter hotels. For the real thing,go to Serekunda market for 8 Dalasi in a white minivans and be prepared for a contrast....

reviews.title: Definitely visit
reviews.text: It's worth a stroll. Numerous small shops offer a variety of items. Highly recommended for soaking up the local atmosphere.

reviews.title: Not for us
reviews.text: At this location – on the Strip – you can't expect everything to be authentic, but it's very tourist-oriented. We didn't really like the atmosphere, perhaps because we were one of the few visitors. Everywhere you stop, they try to sell you something. If you say you're just looking and don't know what you want yet, they say something like "kindness costs nothing." We didn't end up buying anything. We're more into memories and photos anyway. But in this case, we didn't really find the products to be our thing, though that's just a personal preference, of course.

reviews.title: You should visit it sometime
reviews.text: Many small shops offer all sorts of things for tourists, and the atmosphere is friendly if you can relate to African customs. Whether you can find bargains depends on what you're looking for and what you're willing to pay for it.

reviews.title: Not bad but not great
reviews.text: Theres a lot of hassle, but thats what you can expect from anywhere here. Most of the stalls have the exact same things but there are a couple of very nice ones selling a few nicer pieces at the far end of the market. For a more authentic experience, go to the Serrekunda craft market.

reviews.title: Definitely worth a visit
reviews.text: At the beginning of the strip is this craft market. It's nothing special, as there are many such markets in Gambia, but we walked there from our hotel. It's a kind of community, because if you can't find something at one stall, the vendor simply gets it from another. The wood carvings are generally not of high quality. There is a good woodcarver in the back left corner, though. Everything can be made to order. Haggling, like everywhere in Gambia, is a game that has to be played.

reviews.title: Hustle and bustle but mostly just hassle
reviews.text:
Overall

Lots to see, a small market and somewhere you could spend everyday browsing. The merchandise is mostly wood carvings, key rings, material bags and general touristic souvenirs. 

However it is such a shame because it's just not worthwhile rooting around given the amount of hassle you get to enter the stalls and buy something.

Vendors favourite words "come inside it does not cost anything to look and then you go" fat chance! You will be harassed to go in and harassed until you buy something!

They are very friendly people, the Gambians. However they have not realised that they are likely to sell more if they back off a little and let tourists browse.

Worth a visit to see the market but we have been here for four days and still have not mustered the courage to return.

reviews.title: Nice little market at the beginning of the strip
reviews.text: The Senegambia Craft Market is a small but charming market at the beginning of the strip, selling wood carvings, textiles, jewelry, and a wide variety of souvenirs. Simply browsing is nearly impossible; everyone will try to sell you something. A polite gesture of "just browsing" can work wonders. Bargaining is essential at this market too!

reviews.title: Great experience
reviews.text: It's really nice if you just take the time to talk to people and look at their trade. They appreciate it when you take the time for them and will certainly not blame you if you don't buy anything.

reviews.title: Hmm . . it all rather looked the same
reviews.text: Near the top of the strip, the craft market seems to be stocked with imported goods than locally crafted ones, and most of the stalls looked very similar.  There were some batik stalls which broke up the monopoly of the bangles, beads and baubles most of the other stalls had

reviews.title: nice, but commercial
reviews.text: It's a nice market, the goods are actually made there, but you are very bothered to actually buy something.

reviews.title: not very interesting
reviews.text: A lot of standard tourist nic nacs and every man/woman tries to get you in his job. At the entrance you've a few fruit stalls with really nice ladies working there, without the aggressive approach.

reviews.title: Nice little local market
reviews.text: It's worth taking a stroll through the market; there's all sorts of touristy items for sale, and the vendors are friendly. At the entrance is a small shop (Mama Africa), where a sweet old woman sells cigarettes at reasonable prices, among other things.

reviews.title: Nice material but very pushy
reviews.text: You'll find everything you need to take home a nice souvenir, but be sure to haggle because their prices are through the roof!

reviews.title: Please visit !
reviews.text: You can get all your need here ..Try  to be fair and not to beat their price down to much ! These peoples work hard all day  making there goods They need your support !

reviews.title: Типичный туристический рынок
reviews.text: Хороший рынок с большим выбором туристических сувениров. Начальные цены достаточно высокие, поэтому обязательно нужно торговаться. Можно купить неплохие поделки местных жителей.

reviews.title: Nice stuff
reviews.text: This was included in our two-day tour of the Gambian interior. Very pushy, but just let them know you're there to look around. If you want to buy something, they charge Toubab prices, for example. They charge 1700 dal for a bowl and a dish, so the best offer is, say, 100. Way too low... you'll end up with a few hundred, or 700. I thought that was a great price.

reviews.title: Souvenir market
reviews.text: It's a small market where almost every stall sells the same thing. Wooden figures of different sizes, kettledrums, necklaces, bracelets, etc. If you like haggling, it can be entertaining; you can buy things at very good prices. If you just want to browse and not buy anything, it's best not to go looking at anything, because they'll try to sell you anything. They're quite insistent.

reviews.title: Running the gauntlet
reviews.text: I love this craft market but it is not for the faint-hearted.  If you love to barter, don't mind a bit of hassle as you try to find what you are looking for, then you could really enjoy yourself here. Nice little local café at the entrance where for just a little money you can sample the local food, fresh fruit and cold drinks available too at the entrance.  My advice here is to keep your sense of humour, don't get dragged inside the stalls as you WILL not get out without buying something you may not want, but enjoy the fun, the bartering and the genuine openness of the lovely Gambian people. They are trying to earn a living, if you respect them, they will respect you.  Never pay the asking price, it will usually be at least double what they expect you to pay! Fabulous clothes and jewellery and lots of wonderful wooden artefacts to take home as souvenirs. There are even tailors who will whip up an outfit for you in very little time for very fair prices.  Happy shopping and smile!

reviews.title: Great experience
reviews.text: Always worth a visit when staying in Kololi. If in doubt take an official guide with you. Excellent value. They really know their stuff and will help you with any haggling, language difficulties etc.

reviews.title: market day
reviews.text: i went to the market every time i went to gambia great experience but keep in mind you will get pulled in every stall and they think you should buy from everyone you have to be harsh and say no a lot and only pay half of what they ask or less and be willing to walk away go back the next day and you will get a good deal

reviews.title: Great for souvenirs
reviews.text: Great market for souvenirs! The stall owners can be pushy, but remember you don't have to buy everything they ask you too!

reviews.title: Great shopping
reviews.text: Barta everyone sells similar things.. Material heaven bangles jewellery and ornaments, a must visit for all

reviews.title: Souvenir heaven
reviews.text: It's a nice market if you want to buy some souvenirs for the people at home. Everybody wants to sell so don't be intimidated by them.  I had a jumpsuit made by hand and I love it!

reviews.title: nice items
reviews.text: was an experience, was quiet at this time of year, you do get hassled but think thats part of the experience.

reviews.title: Good for some souvenirs
reviews.text: This is a very small craft market in the strip, where you can buy some souvenirs and you don't have to suffer the terrible smell of bigger markets such as the one in Banjul. Ready yourself for sellers telling you to stop at their stall constantly and some haggling.  It opens around 10 am and opens around 8 pm.

reviews.title: Nothing out of the ordinary.
reviews.text: Lots of beads, clothing, beachwear, trinkets, wooden articles all rough hewn, nothing much to catch my eye and a bit too pushy stall vendors for my liking.

reviews.title: Great   shopping  a  must,
reviews.text:
A  must,  great  place  a  bit  rough  under  foot  in  places but  the  people    selling  do  bother  you  a bit
but  a  polite  no  thanks  does  the  job,  I  just  love  the  atmosphere  with  the  bartering  to  get  bargins   I  will
be  back in  November  2015   and  back  to  the  market,

reviews.title: A good place to buy pressies for friends back home
reviews.text:
However, it can be a bit too pushy for you to buy something.  I wish the traders would back off and just let you have a good browse, take it in and buy what you want.  

However, not a bad place to be.

reviews.title: Pushy...busy
reviews.text: Never again!!!! A truly awful experience. However, it's a Gambian experience, and one I've experienced from my own experience. I was there with a good friend. The entire stay was a nightmare. Never a moment of peace due to pushiness. I've learned to always do my research before booking a trip. Tip: never go to this market alone as a woman unless you're familiar with it.

reviews.title: Very nice place
reviews.text:
A very nice and friendly place. Lots of excellent crafts and good prices. 
Friendly people.
Recommended for everyone.

reviews.title: Craft Market
reviews.text: this craft market is nice and pleasant to walk round but you do get stopped a lot with the stall holders so it takes longer to get round, all the stalls seem to be selling the same stuff

reviews.title: Nice crafts but pricey
reviews.text: Its a lovely place to visit but you have to be armed with your haggling skills if you intend buying when go here as things are abit pricey and sellers alway try to out-buck you for a higher deal

reviews.title: A busy place
reviews.text:
The craft market is purely for the tourists but the skills on show are long lost in the UK.
The woodcarving, tie and die fabrics, ceramics, stuff made from rubbish and turned into art... brilliant.

reviews.title: gambia at its best.
reviews.text: people are nice,very polite,we ate a lot outside of the hotel&the senegambia strip with the locals.if u ask a local what he /she wants to eat its always chicken.

reviews.title: OK if you like wood carvings and batik
reviews.text: You need to haggle or you wil pay over the odds. Not a lot to buy unless you like wood carvings ,batik and beaded jewellery.

reviews.title: meeting locals
reviews.text: very interesting visit although the smell at certain stalls can be sickly. one thing to be wary of is some of the locals do not like you taking photos or videos of them. they can get annoyed with you. something to do with taking the spirit out of their bodies.

reviews.title: Avoid at all costs
reviews.text: The bumsters are really out in force here. Every cubicle feels like a danger zone. You get hassled non stop and I felt very threatened and could not wait to get away.

reviews.title: small cozy market
reviews.text: The Senegambia Craft Market is a small but charming market at the beginning of the strip, selling wood carvings, textiles, jewelry, and a wide variety of souvenirs. Simply browsing is nearly impossible; everyone will try to sell you something. A polite gesture of "just browsing" can work wonders. Bargaining is essential at this market too!

reviews.title: Overpriced
reviews.text: Expect quite a lot of hassle; much more interesting and better value at Serrekunda market (which is probably the source of many of the goods on sale here!)

reviews.title: bargain hunting
reviews.text: a lovely market brilliant for carvings and afican jewellery etc lots of fun bartering offer then about a third of the price they quote please visit Gambia no ebola there they need tourism

reviews.title: Geweldige markt
reviews.text: Zeg dat je rustig wil kijken, en alles wil zien en niet van opdringerige verkoop houdt, en alles komt goed

reviews.title: leuke markt , niet al te groot
reviews.text:
leuke dingen , maar rustig kijken valt niet mee .
als je ergens kijkt moet je gelijk in de shop komen want kijken kost niets , hahahaa ja dat weten we .

reviews.title: Mobbed
reviews.text: We cannot tell you too much as we didn't stay long enough! You were mobbed from all sides as soon as you enter and it can be intimidating. What we did see was very run of the mill tourist tat tha t you get in all holiday resorts. There is no such thing as browsing in this market, I wouldn't recommend going although with very little else to do in the so called resort I guess they have a captive market.

reviews.title: Plenty to see and do
reviews.text: Very busy, great to experience African life.  Haggle and hunt for some bargains!  You can buy anything here from fish, meat and vegetables to cocoa butter moisturiser to clothes dye!  We bought some pencils to give out to local children in the villages.

reviews.title: Typical market
reviews.text: Good market with plenty to browse around, be ready to barter and you will have a great experience all tastes catered for!

reviews.title: good local market
reviews.text: all locals go here,great market to get the local feel of gambia,we had local guide,explained everything,not much to buy,but great experience

reviews.title: Nothing bad, just all a bit the same as any other.
reviews.text: The stalls are all very much the same as you find else where, carvings, shells, jewellery, drums, cloths etc. Store holders, not too hasslesome like some others. Didn't buy anything as nothing that took my eye. The ladies selling fruit and nuts are nice and very friendly, would go there again to get supplies. Do drive a hard bargain though.

reviews.title: worth a visit
reviews.text: was fun bartering give it a go!!  lots of tourist items to buy cheaper than the hotels, so worth a visit

reviews.title: Crowdy but interesting
reviews.text: Definitely a place to have a look at for the brave. Be aware of the hassling. Be firm but polite and there is a lot of goodies to find.

reviews.title: great
reviews.text: a great place to pick up a bargin. Do not be put off by the haggling they do expect it. A good tip is to go in the evening about 7 before they close

reviews.title: Senegambia Craft Market
reviews.text: This is Africa! expect to be hassled, expect to be cajoled, expect to bargain for items. Always be smiley and pleasant, ideally the first time you visit look only, do n't touch or even ask prices. Reflect on what you want and return another day, then look and touch ! The products are cheap anyway but always barter, excellent fabric, wood carvings and jewellery.

reviews.title: Local craftsware as usual
reviews.text: The craft market is nearby the "Strip" and you find all craft workers concentrated on one spot. So not many sellers borders you on the beach and in the streets.

reviews.title: Leuk
reviews.text: Hier maken ze allerlei handwerkjes. tafelkleden,doeken,beelden en sieraden bijvoorbeeld op de traditionele manier

reviews.title: hassled
reviews.text: would of loved to of stayed and shopped here as such beautiful things, but was hassled too much and to afraid to look. if they didn't keep pestering you ,would og bought things, as it was we just left with nothing

reviews.title: Do it and try it
reviews.text:
Try this craft market, nice people and they have it all, good prices with quality products.
Visit stand number 56 - ask for Rake - Quality products and good prices.

reviews.title: nice!
reviews.text: It's a really fun market. As you've probably read, you'll never go home empty-handed. And if you go home with more than you thought you'd buy, you've overpaid ;-) But everyone wants to sell something! It's all free, so even if it's just a cheerfully colored bamboo bracelet, feel free to bring it along!

reviews.title: Never walk away without anything
reviews.text: Friendly sellers of handmade wooden items. You're always welcome to join them for lunch, which is what I did. I'll definitely be back for more beautiful items.

reviews.title: not your typical market
reviews.text: A bit hectic but interesting, noisy  but friendly, some of the stall holders tried their very best but alas not all were successful

reviews.title: Good experience
reviews.text:
Very busy and bustling market, lots of stalls selling, fruit/veg products, fabrics souvenirs and local craft items.
Be prepared for the selling culture and to haggle down the prices of items.

reviews.title: What an afull place
reviews.text: Not only they pretend to make it by themselves (all is imported from abroad) they will surround you and all at the same time try to drag you to their shop (often arguing with you) that they have what you want (even though I say nothing what I am looking for). If you want a souvenir then go in there in group with something on your mind and leave quickly or you can but at shops.

reviews.title: Nice market with local handicrafts
reviews.text: A wide selection of locally made wood carvings, jewelry, and textiles. Bargaining is common.

reviews.title: Nice market
reviews.text: Nice little market to wander around. It's a shame you get accosted by all the vendors trying to buy something. It's easy to get bored and leave.

reviews.title: Silly prices African craft market
reviews.text: A good selection of arts and crafts, some nice pieces and some not so nice.  The prices are ridiculous at the offset coupled with pushy overzealous sellers.  These things cost pittance to make in comparison to the retail.  Their is a premium to pay as a foreigner and this is exploited relentlessly by sellers trying to sell goods at far beyond their worth.  You can haggle but you will never be able to pay a fair price.  If you crave attention and have money is not a concern then you will like this place and they in turn will love you.

reviews.title: SENEGAMBIA CRAFT MARKET
reviews.text: Senegambia Craft Market is right on the beautiful tourist strip at Kololi. To get there, head down the Bertil Harding Highway southbound until you get to the Senegambia Junction. The Highway and Junction are bitumen roads straight from Banjul Airport, which really helps as many roads are not surfaced in Gambia. The Craft Market is right on the crossroads and surrounded by Restaurants such as the excellent Gaya Art Café on the highway and popular African Queen Restaurant just around the corner near Totties Nightclub. The Craft Market is in a thriving tourist area and there you will find many locally made souvenirs to buy and bring home while stopping off to have a drink or meal in the area on the way to or from Kololi Beach. You can watch the wood carvers making traditional African masks and ornaments. You may see sand painters at work, buy some art or hand-made jewellery, try some local food, buy fruit and juice, and see tailors sewing on treadle sewing machines making pretty sun dresses for women and children as well as traditional African clothing. You can even have a tailor make you an outfit, and I have had a made-to-measure dress or two made there myself. I can personally recommend Fatou Jagne who has a tailor's business in the market as that is where I had my first traditional African outfit made-to-measure on a trip to Gambia. Perhaps you will even catch some djembe players in action or just buy one of these beautifully made traditional drums to take home. I've seen many wrapped up going through the departures queue at Banjul Yundum Airport. The musicians are not there all the time, but the carvers who make the djembe drums might just show you how to play one if you want to try. Prices there vary slightly and the traders can be haggled with but please do be polite and reasonable as they have overheads to pay, families to support and “hand-made” in any part of the world takes time. Don't forget that materials cost money too. Their art and crafting is their job not a hobby and they are all very nice people keen to please. One wood carver made me a wooden fish ornament for my brother while I watched, though fish were not his usual thing to carve. The people working there are open to suggestions and keen to help. The thing I like about it being situated right on Senegambia Junction is that at the side of the Craft Market there is a police checkpoint and the officers there will ensure that no tourist is hassled or harassed. It's one of my favorite spots in Gambia and I stay in the Kololi area frequently.
